hook.text: In 1947, a Harvard computer stopped working. The cause was literally a moth stuck in a relay.

buildup.text: Grace Hopper's team taped the moth into the logbook and labeled it 'first actual case of bug found.'

discovery.text: The term 'bug' predates computers, but this incident cemented it in programming culture.

twist.text: Today, software bugs cost the global economy over $1.7 trillion per year.

climax.text: A tiny insect became the mascot for the biggest ongoing problem in technology.

punchline.text: One moth started a trillion-dollar problem.

quiz.question: Where was the first literal computer bug found?

hook.text: The average programmer writes about 10 bugs per 1,000 lines of code.

buildup.text: Modern software runs on millions of lines. Even tiny error rates produce thousands of flaws.

discovery.text: Complexity is the root cause. As code grows, the number of possible states explodes.

twist.text: Testing can prove bugs exist but can never prove they're all gone.

climax.text: Dijkstra said testing shows the presence of bugs, not their absence. He was right.

punchline.text: Perfect software is a mathematical impossibility.

quiz.question: What did Dijkstra say about testing?
options: It shows the presence of bugs, not their absence
It is unnecessary for good code

hook.text: As midnight approached on January 1, 2000, the world held its breath.

buildup.text: Old programs stored years as two digits. The year 2000 would register as 1900.

discovery.text: Banks, power grids, and hospitals all ran code written decades earlier with this shortcut.

twist.text: Governments spent over $300 billion fixing Y2K bugs. When midnight hit, almost nothing broke.

climax.text: Critics called it a hoax. Engineers knew the fix worked because they spent years applying it.

punchline.text: The disaster that didn't happen was the fix working.

quiz.question: How much was spent globally to fix Y2K bugs?

hook.text: The two hardest problems in computer science: cache invalidation, naming things, and off-by-one errors.

buildup.text: An off-by-one error happens when code counts one too many or one too few iterations.

discovery.text: Fencepost problems are everywhere. Ten fence sections need eleven posts, not ten.

twist.text: These tiny mistakes cause buffer overflows â€” one of the most exploited security holes in history.

climax.text: Billion-dollar systems have crashed because a loop ran one extra time.

punchline.text: The smallest error is often the deadliest.

quiz.question: What is a fencepost problem?

topics.title: The Cost of Late Bug Fixes

hook.text: Finding a bug during design costs $1 to fix. Finding it in production costs $100.

buildup.text: IBM's research showed that bug-fix costs grow exponentially the later they're discovered.

discovery.text: A typo caught in code review takes minutes. The same typo in a live system takes an emergency team.

twist.text: Despite knowing this, most companies still skip early testing to ship features faster.

climax.text: The cheapest bug fix is the one that never ships. Prevention always beats repair.

punchline.text: Every shortcut now becomes an emergency later.

quiz.question: How do bug-fix costs change as software moves toward production?

hook.text: On June 4, 1996, a brand-new European rocket exploded 37 seconds after liftoff.

buildup.text: Ariane 5 reused navigation software from its predecessor, Ariane 4.

discovery.text: A 64-bit number was squeezed into a 16-bit space. The overflow crashed the guidance system.

twist.text: The faulty code wasn't even needed during flight. It ran a pre-launch calibration check.

climax.text: Half a billion dollars of cargo destroyed by a single type conversion error.

punchline.text: A data type mismatch blew up a rocket.

quiz.question: What caused the Ariane 5 rocket to explode?
options: A fuel leak in the engine
A communication failure with ground control

hook.text: In 1999, NASA lost a $125 million spacecraft because of a unit conversion mistake.

buildup.text: Lockheed Martin's code used imperial units. NASA's system expected metric.

discovery.text: Thruster data in pound-seconds was read as newton-seconds, sending the craft off course.

twist.text: The orbiter flew too close to Mars and disintegrated in the atmosphere.

climax.text: Two teams working on the same project never agreed on which unit system to use.

punchline.text: Metric versus imperial destroyed a spacecraft.

quiz.question: What caused the loss of the Mars Climate Orbiter?

hook.text: Three minutes before the Moon landing, alarms blared in the lunar module.

buildup.text: The computer threw 1202 and 1201 errors â€” executive overflow. Too many tasks, too little memory.

discovery.text: A mistakenly left-on radar switch was flooding the computer with unnecessary data.

twist.text: The software was designed to prioritize. It dropped low-priority tasks and kept landing on track.

climax.text: Margaret Hamilton's priority system saved the mission. The landing succeeded.

punchline.text: Good error handling landed humans on the Moon.

quiz.question: What saved the Apollo 11 landing during the computer alarms?

hook.text: Two brand-new Boeing 737 MAX planes crashed within five months, killing 346 people.

buildup.text: A software system called MCAS was designed to prevent stalls by pushing the nose down.

discovery.text: MCAS relied on a single sensor. When that sensor failed, it forced the plane into a dive.

twist.text: Pilots weren't told MCAS existed. They fought a system they didn't know was controlling the plane.

climax.text: The crashes exposed how cost-cutting in software testing can have fatal consequences.

punchline.text: Hidden software with no redundancy killed 346 people.

quiz.question: What was the critical flaw in the Boeing 737 MAX's MCAS system?
options: It relied on a single sensor
It couldn't connect to the internet

hook.text: In 1962, NASA destroyed a Venus-bound rocket 293 seconds after launch.

buildup.text: Mariner 1 veered off course and had to be self-destructed over the Atlantic.

discovery.text: A missing overbar in a handwritten formula was transcribed wrong into the guidance code.

twist.text: One tiny punctuation mark in the specification caused an $18 million loss.

climax.text: Arthur C. Clarke called it 'the most expensive hyphen in history.'

punchline.text: A missing symbol destroyed a space mission.

quiz.question: What did Arthur C. Clarke call the Mariner 1 failure?
options: The most expensive hyphen in history

hook.text: Between 1985 and 1987, a radiation therapy machine gave patients lethal overdoses.

buildup.text: The Therac-25 relied entirely on software safety checks, removing all hardware interlocks.

discovery.text: A race condition let the machine fire full-power beams when operators typed commands too fast.

twist.text: The manufacturer blamed hospitals. They insisted their software was tested and safe.

climax.text: Six patients were severely injured or killed. The case rewrote software safety standards.

punchline.text: Software replaced safety hardware and people died.

quiz.question: What type of bug caused the Therac-25 overdoses?

hook.text: In 1991, a Patriot missile battery failed to intercept an incoming Scud. Twenty-eight soldiers died.

buildup.text: The system's internal clock measured time in tenths of seconds using a 24-bit register.

discovery.text: A tiny rounding error of 0.000000095 seconds accumulated over 100 hours of operation.

twist.text: After 100 hours, the clock had drifted by a third of a second â€” enough to miss a Scud.

climax.text: The Army knew about the bug and issued a patch, but it arrived one day too late.

punchline.text: A rounding error of a billionth cost 28 lives.

quiz.question: What caused the Patriot missile system to fail?
options: Accumulated clock drift from rounding errors

hook.text: On August 14, 2003, the lights went out for 55 million people across the northeastern US.

buildup.text: Power lines sagged into trees in Ohio, triggering a cascading overload across the grid.

discovery.text: The alarm system that should have warned operators had crashed due to a software race condition.

twist.text: Operators saw no alerts for over an hour while the grid spiraled into collapse.

climax.text: A silent software failure turned a local problem into the largest blackout in North American history.

punchline.text: A silent alarm plunged 55 million into darkness.

quiz.question: What software failure contributed to the 2003 Northeast blackout?
options: The alarm system crashed from a race condition
A virus attacked the power grid

hook.text: Starting in 2009, Toyota cars began accelerating on their own. Over 89 people died.

buildup.text: Toyota initially blamed floor mats and sticky pedals, denying any software involvement.

discovery.text: Expert analysis found spaghetti code with 10,000 global variables and no fail-safe architecture.

twist.text: The code lacked basic protections. A single bit flip could trigger unintended full throttle.

climax.text: Toyota paid over $1.2 billion in settlements and recalled millions of vehicles worldwide.

punchline.text: Ten thousand global variables cost lives and billions.

quiz.question: What did expert analysis find in Toyota's software?

hook.text: On October 1, 2013, the US launched HealthCare.gov. It crashed almost immediately.

buildup.text: The site was supposed to serve millions of Americans shopping for health insurance.

discovery.text: Only six people managed to enroll on the first day. The site could handle just 1,100 users.

twist.text: Fifty-five contractors built pieces that were never properly integrated or load-tested.

climax.text: A rescue team of top engineers rebuilt the site in weeks, saving the entire program.

punchline.text: The biggest launch failure became a rescue story.

quiz.question: How many people enrolled on HealthCare.gov's first day?

hook.text: On August 1, 2012, Knight Capital lost $440 million in just 45 minutes.

buildup.text: A technician deployed new trading code but forgot to update it on one of eight servers.

discovery.text: The old code on that server started buying high and selling low at machine speed.

twist.text: Nobody noticed for 45 minutes. By then, the company was effectively bankrupt.

climax.text: Knight Capital was sold days later. A missed deployment destroyed a billion-dollar firm.

punchline.text: One missed server update killed a company in 45 minutes.

quiz.question: How much did Knight Capital lose due to the software glitch?

hook.text: On May 6, 2010, the Dow Jones dropped nearly 1,000 points in minutes, then bounced back.

buildup.text: High-frequency trading algorithms detected selling pressure and amplified it at machine speed.

discovery.text: One large sell order triggered a feedback loop among thousands of automated trading bots.

twist.text: Procter & Gamble stock briefly traded at one cent. Accenture dropped to a penny per share.

climax.text: A trillion dollars in market value vanished and returned within 20 minutes.

punchline.text: Algorithms panicked faster than humans ever could.

quiz.question: What caused the 2010 Flash Crash?
options: A feedback loop among trading algorithms
A power outage at the stock exchange

topics.title: The Excel Error That Rocked Economics

hook.text: In 2010, two Harvard economists published a paper that influenced austerity policies worldwide.

buildup.text: Reinhart and Rogoff claimed high national debt always crushed economic growth.

discovery.text: A grad student found they had accidentally excluded five countries from their Excel formula.

twist.text: The corrected data showed no clear debt threshold. The original conclusion was wrong.

climax.text: Governments had already cut budgets based on the flawed paper, affecting millions of people.

punchline.text: A spreadsheet mistake shaped global economic policy.

quiz.question: What error did the Reinhart-Rogoff paper contain?
options: Countries excluded from an Excel formula

hook.text: In 2012, JPMorgan Chase lost $6.2 billion on risky trades that slipped past risk controls.

buildup.text: A trader in London made massive bets on credit derivatives that kept growing.

discovery.text: The risk model used a spreadsheet that divided by a sum instead of an average.

twist.text: The error cut the apparent risk in half. The true exposure was double what managers saw.

climax.text: A copy-paste formula error helped hide billions in risk from the largest US bank.

punchline.text: A formula error hid six billion in losses.

quiz.question: What spreadsheet error contributed to JPMorgan's $6.2 billion loss?
options: Dividing by a sum instead of an average

hook.text: In August 2010, someone created 184 billion Bitcoin out of thin air.

buildup.text: Bitcoin's code checked individual outputs but not the total. An integer overflow slipped through.

discovery.text: The transaction created coins far beyond the 21 million limit, breaking Bitcoin's core promise.

twist.text: Developers caught it within hours and rolled back the blockchain with an emergency patch.

climax.text: The incident proved that even decentralized, trustless systems depend on human code reviews.

punchline.text: An overflow nearly destroyed digital scarcity.

quiz.question: What type of bug created 184 billion Bitcoin?

hook.text: In 2014, security researchers discovered a flaw that exposed the private data of millions.

buildup.text: Heartbleed was a bug in OpenSSL, the encryption library used by two-thirds of web servers.

discovery.text: A missing bounds check let attackers read server memory, stealing passwords and encryption keys.

twist.text: The bug existed for over two years before anyone noticed. One volunteer had introduced it.

climax.text: The internet's security depended on underfunded open-source code maintained by a few people.

punchline.text: One missing check exposed half the internet.

quiz.question: What caused the Heartbleed vulnerability?
options: A missing bounds check in OpenSSL

hook.text: On November 2, 1988, the internet slowed to a crawl. Something was eating all the bandwidth.

buildup.text: Robert Morris, a Cornell grad student, released a self-replicating program to measure the internet.

discovery.text: A bug made the worm copy itself too aggressively, infecting machines over and over.

twist.text: About 10% of all internet-connected computers â€” roughly 6,000 â€” were knocked offline.

climax.text: Morris became the first person convicted under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

punchline.text: An experiment to measure the web nearly killed it.

quiz.question: What was the Morris Worm originally intended to do?
options: Measure the size of the internet

hook.text: In 2017, hackers stole the personal data of 147 million Americans from a credit bureau.

buildup.text: Equifax held names, Social Security numbers, and addresses for nearly every US adult.

discovery.text: Attackers exploited a known vulnerability in Apache Struts. A patch had been available for months.

twist.text: Equifax knew about the flaw but failed to apply the update. Internal security scans also failed.

climax.text: The breach cost Equifax over $1.4 billion and exposed systemic negligence in corporate security.

punchline.text: A patch existed for months. Nobody applied it.

quiz.question: How many Americans were affected by the Equifax breach?

hook.text: In December 2021, a flaw in a tiny Java library put millions of servers at risk overnight.

buildup.text: Log4j was an open-source logging tool embedded in almost every Java application on Earth.

discovery.text: Attackers could send a crafted text string that made servers execute any remote code.

twist.text: One volunteer maintained the critical library part-time. Nobody had audited it.

climax.text: Log4Shell exposed how modern software depends on invisible, underfunded open-source components.

punchline.text: The internet ran on a library nobody was watching.

quiz.question: What was Log4j?

hook.text: In 2010, centrifuges at Iran's nuclear facility started spinning themselves to destruction.

buildup.text: A worm called Stuxnet targeted specific industrial controllers made by Siemens.

discovery.text: It sabotaged centrifuge speeds while sending normal readings to operators. They saw nothing wrong.

twist.text: Stuxnet was likely built by the US and Israel â€” the first known cyber weapon used against a nation.

climax.text: Software crossed from the digital world into physical destruction for the first time.

punchline.text: Code became a weapon of war.

quiz.question: What did Stuxnet physically destroy?

hook.text: The Therac-25 removed hardware safety interlocks and trusted software alone. People died.

buildup.text: Defense in depth means stacking multiple independent safety layers so no single failure is fatal.

discovery.text: Airplanes use triple-redundant computers. If one fails, two others keep flying the plane.

twist.text: Boeing's 737 MAX ignored this principle for MCAS, relying on one sensor. The result was tragedy.

climax.text: Every catastrophic failure in this course shares one trait: a single point of failure.

punchline.text: Never trust one layer to catch every mistake.

quiz.question: What is the core idea behind defense in depth?
options: Using only the best single solution
Removing all software from safety systems

hook.text: The Heartbleed bug sat in OpenSSL's code for two years before anyone noticed.

buildup.text: One developer wrote the code. One reviewer approved it. Nobody else looked.

discovery.text: Studies show code review catches 60-90% of defects â€” far more than testing alone.

twist.text: Speed pressure makes teams skip reviews. They save hours now and lose weeks debugging later.

climax.text: The cheapest security tool is a second pair of eyes reading your code before it ships.

punchline.text: Two eyes miss what four eyes catch.

quiz.question: What percentage of defects can code review catch according to studies?

hook.text: The Ariane 5 software was tested thoroughly â€” for the Ariane 4. Nobody tested it for the new rocket.

buildup.text: Testing runs code with specific inputs. Formal verification proves code works for all inputs.

discovery.text: NASA uses formal methods for spacecraft. They mathematically prove critical code is correct.

twist.text: Verification is expensive and slow, so most companies skip it. They test and hope for the best.

climax.text: When lives depend on code, hoping is not a strategy. Proof beats probability.

punchline.text: Testing finds some bugs. Proof eliminates them.

quiz.question: How does formal verification differ from testing?
options: It proves code works for all inputs

hook.text: Knight Capital's disaster started when a technician missed one server during deployment.

buildup.text: Humans make errors under time pressure, fatigue, and complexity. Software can't fix that alone.

discovery.text: Checklists, automation, and blameless postmortems reduce human error more than punishment does.

twist.text: Blaming individuals feels satisfying but misses systemic problems that caused the mistake.

climax.text: The best organizations treat every failure as a system design problem, not a people problem.

punchline.text: Blame the system, not the person.

quiz.question: What approach do the best organizations take after failures?
options: Treat them as system design problems

hook.text: Race conditions crashed Therac-25 in 1985 and the Northeast power grid in 2003.

buildup.text: The same categories of bugs â€” overflows, race conditions, missing checks â€” appear decade after decade.

discovery.text: New developers rarely study old failures. They learn languages and frameworks, not disaster history.

twist.text: Organizations lose institutional memory when senior engineers leave or teams reorganize.

climax.text: History doesn't repeat, but the bugs rhyme. Learning from failure is the only real defense.

punchline.text: Those who don't study old bugs are doomed to ship them.

quiz.question: Why do the same types of software bugs keep appearing?
options: New developers don't study past failures
